Summary: The system seems to partially crash when you start the screensaver. Task: Start FreeNAS in a VM, and see if you can reproduce the problem.
Description: FreeNAS is a program to turn a regular PC into a networked hard disk appliance, aka network attached storage device. In this task, you need to install FreeNAS by reading its documentation -- perhaps installing it in a virtual machine -- and see if the steps listed by the submitter of the bug also cause your FreeNAS install to require a reboot.

Summary: Start a FreeNAS virtual machine and try to use it, on Windows, with a screen reader. Then, if you can, fix the Python FreeNAS code so it works better for blind people
Description: The ticket links to a discussion on the FreeNAS web forums. Read the conversation there, and install FreeNAS into a virtual machine or physical computer. Once you do that, install screen reading software to see how it treats the adm interface. See if you can reproduce the problematic behavior, which is that the screen reader doesn't read all of the menus

Summary: To fix font issues, make the javascript change suggested by a prior contributor and see if it solves the problem.

Find out how DocuWiki makes code blocks downloadable, and make that available for MediaWiki users
Description: It's a feature, not a bug!

Summary: Test if the docs are still missing, and if so, say so

Summary: Spend 30-60 minutes reviewing provided example code, and see if you can improve it by following the style guide. Your work helps psychologists put experiments together!

Required skills: Tahoe-LAFS basics, willingness to read about cryptography
Summary: Get to know what a "convergence secret" is, and how it relates to the Tahoe filesystem, and submit a corresponding change to the documentation
Fix a typo in an email that the system sends out. In particular, it seems the message *body* says "to to" when it should say "to", and the message *subject* may contain the wrong person's name.
WordPress has a built-in way to list what media items are "attached" to which blog posts. The functionality, written in PHP, should be extended to be able to filter by file type, AKA MIME type.
Description: Feature request; clearly useful; semi difficult

Summary: yes
Description: Requires making a color decision that will likely be overridden by WP devs...

Summary: Refresh (and improve comments on) a WordPress patch that already exists. The patch improves WordPress by letting it use just one redirect where it used to use two redirects.
Description: It "just" requires refreshing the patch

Summary: For any open source project, find the users and answer their questions!
For any open source project, make sure it works for a speaker of your non-English language.
Make sure you can reproduce this bug in Firefox on your platform. If so, say so on the ticket. Test it both on the official svg-edit demo site, and on a local install.
Reorganize how they bundle code to use "requireJS". (Difficult, but doable if you have JS experience!)
Description: This requires either having, or being willing to learn, some Javascript programming design patterns. In particular, requireJS is one of a few different new tools for helping Javascript files indicate what other Javascript files they rely on. The task is to take the existing svg-edit code, read the document for requireJS, and attempt to add requireJS headers to the svg-edit code. Once you have the beginnings of that, submit it as a patch for discussion on the ticket.

Summary: Make sure you can reproduce this bug. If so, say so.
Fix this documentation bug -- remove or update the broken links. (First, make sure it still exists! Either way, leave a comment on the bug.)
Description: Notes from previous attendee: Cloning the repo shows .../Classes.html does not exist. .../Interfaces.html does not exist either. Cannot replicate second part of issue. (outdated?)

Summary: Read this UI bug, and see if you can change the UI to match the suggestion. (Difficulty: high!)
Another contributor offered a patch for a bug two years ago but it was never acted upon.  See if these bugs still exist, and see if this patch still fixes the issue.
Description: You can use what you learned in the diffpatch OpenHatch training mission to apply the patch. Note that if the patch tool complains that the patch does not apply, even that is useful feedback. If you are interested in "forward-porting" the patch, which is to say, interested in taking the code submitted and adjusting it to work as a change against the current version of svg-edit, that would be even better.

Summary: See if this patched Brazilian Portuguese localization still applies. If so, ask for commit access to commit it! If not, say so, and consider seeing if you can make it apply by manually making the same changes.
See if you can reproduce this problem, where receiving an APK file by email fails
Description: To do this, you'll need to install K-9 on your phone and be able to find an APK file (e.g. on the web) to send yourself by email.

Summary: See if you can reproduce this problem where svg-editor.html does not work properly, for version 2.5.1 when downloaded
Description: All that is required here is to download version 2.5.1 of the svg-edit app and run it in your web browser. If you find it does not work properly in the way described, leave an update to say so on the bug report.

Required skills: Use software on the web, use Firefox
Summary: Display problem.  Latest comment to issue claims bug is fixed in Firefox 21.  Check and either confirm or deny.
Description: All that is required is to try using Firefox 21 to test the app. If so, or if not, leave a comment on the bug to say as much.

Summary: Add a menu item to automatically download the SVG data

Required skills: Use an Android app, answer questions
Summary: Read this bug report, and see if you can explain to the user if the functionality exists that they want (as well as gently point them to the support forum rather than the bug tracker)
Fix this off-by-one error, where the folder that gets remembered is always exactly one folder ahead of what should have been remembered (Note: requires writing Java)

Mosh wraps SSH, but does not support SSH's X forwarding feature. Edit the wrapper in scripts/mosh to pass the -x argument to ssh (telling it not to set up X forwarding), then test it (ideally on several platforms)
Description: mosh is a tool for remote login, and it is built on top of SSH. Although it makes its initial connection using SSH, idoesn't support all the features of SSH. In this bug, a user of mosh found that their personal configuration of SSH enabled a feature "X forwarding" that is not supported by mosh. In this bug, someone has proposed a fix where you (dear contributor) would modify mosh so that when it makes that initial connection, it actively declines to enable that feature.
closed: shauna marked as skip. AL not sure why.

Summary: Help us figure out why certain Arabic texts render differently in Mosh
closed: AL should document the next step on that bug, if we want this to be in

Summary: Bug in rendering of title.  Attempt to reproduce and add comment to confirm (or not.)
Description: If you're feeling adventurous, you can also try to fix the issue.  Should require primarily CSS.

Summary: Create a simple function that draws a geometric circle.
Description: ggplot2, which is a library used by programmers who write code in the R programming language, can be used to draw a circle. In this bug, someone complains about how complicated it is to draw a circle with ggplot2 and proposes a simpler interface for it. To really understand this bug, you will need ggplot2 running properly on your own computer, and to try to the current best way to draw a circle, and see ifyou agre with the author that it is more complicated than it needs to be. If you can make a simple fuction for it, you should add that function to the same file(s) that define the current way to draw a circle. Once you're done with that, submit it as a patch or pull request to the project.

Summary: Set up url canonicalisation/redirects for website.
Description: May need to elaborate on the feature.

Summary: Find out if Ekiga still fails to compile with -DSEAL
Description: If you like compiling software on Linux, you'll love this! If not, you will likely find it pretty uninteresting.

Summary: Totem, a video player on Linux, has a browser plugin. It would be cool if it automatically could download streams.
Description: Verify that totem is still lacking this feature. If it is, follow the suggestions in comment #8 to implement a patch.

Summary: Wrap strings in the code file mentioned in the bug with gettext calls where missing.
Description: gettext is used by translation; look at the "Translate some software" task to learn more about that.

Summary: Verify bug (as it is 5 years old!)  If still a bug, modify this GTK app so it saves how big the window was when it last ran
Description: You'll need to learn about GTK callbacks and the on-resize-event. This will be somewhat complicated, but good if you are an experienced C programmer.

Summary: Re-organize preferences in Rhythmbox, a music player
Description: This bug requests re-organizing some preferences. There is a patch, but it seems that the latest version of that patch did not get reviewed. Your role would be to read that patch, and see if it still applies to rhythmbox, perhaps using git to "refresh" the patch so that it does still apply.

Required skills: C, GTK, patch, some experience compiling gtk programs
Summary: Review and apply the patch. If the patch doesn't apply cleanly, reapply the changes and create a new one.
Description: On the Linux-based music player, Rhythmbox, if you import a playlist file, it shows up with the file extension as well -- yourfile.m3u for example. In this patch, the submitter addressed thia behavior. Your goal is to see if the behavior is still present in the current version of Rhythmbox by downloading it and installing it, either from your Linux distribution's package management system, or by downloading and compiling the source code using Git and jhbuild. Note that jhbuid can take a long time. As a clarification, "apply cleanly" means that the patch tool seems to apply the patch without complaint.

Required skills: Basic understanding of feed formats, Python, Windows
Summary: Verify that feeds continue to not work in Internet Explorer. If they still fail, then fix the problem.
Description: This requires knowledge of feed formats, such as RSS and Atom, and a willingness to test in Windows. The file to change is in the gimp-web repository in git.gnome.org. The bug contains information on the probable fix, so you just need to write a patch.

Required skills: C, GTK, patch, some experience compiling gtk programs
Summary: Review and apply the patch. and leave comments in the bug.
Improve image quality for cover art
Description: There is a patch on the ticket. You should attempt to apply it to the latest version of Banshee to see if it still applies. If so, you should say so! If not, share that as well. The discussion says that the patch relies on semi-broken C# bindings, but that bug has been fixed; see https://bugzilla.novell.com/show_bug.cgi?id=681111

Summary: Improve git filter-branch based on a user's bug report
Description: This bug affects complex internal behavior in git, but if you're a git expert, then you might super enjoy this.

Summary: Diagnose the root cause of why git-svn creates weird history
Description: This bug affects complex internal behavior in git, but if you're a git expert, then you might super enjoy this.

Summary: Change an out of date URL in the documentation.
Add documentation of Terminal key compatibility options
Description: Confirm that there's no documentation, investigate how the compatibility key options work, and write up some documentation

Summary: Update documentation on anonymous commenting.
Description: May have to do some experimenting/investigating to see what exactly the FAQ should be updated to.

Summary: Update documentation on HTML tags.
Description: May have to do some experimenting/investigating to see what exactly the FAQ should be updated to.

Summary: Make a small edit (provided by a previous contributor) to some CSS.
Create a plugin which allows users to print a pdf without opening it by right-clicking.
Description: You should be relatively familiar with linux and the concept of plug-ins.  Also it might take a while.

Summary: Help convert single-letter protein alphabet to three-letter protein alphabet.
Description: There's no easy way to convert from the single letter protein alphabet to the three letter.  Another poster suggests an already existing function but it will have to be adapted to fit multiple project-specific object types.

Summary: Verify that a documentation change has been made and, if not, change it.
Description: A user suggested a chance to documentation one month ago.  Check that change was made - if not, make change & submit patch.  If it was, comment asking the issue to be closed.

Summary: Fix how code handles input error so it fails gracefully.
Description: A certain type of invalid input currently causes the software to crash.  Search for the problematic code, and fix it "fails gracefully" - that is, outputs an error message instead of crashing the software.

Summary: Add more automated tests
Description: Add an automated test showing that when pig stores a DateTime object, the data is saved properly.

Summary: Document the BigInteger and BigDecimal data type
Description: In the pig documentation, add documentation for two new data types. Look for existing data types documentation before getting started on this, to make sure you are in the right place to add the new documentation.

Summary: Add New Reserved Keywords To The Pig Docs
Description: The pig documentation doesn't mention all the keywords of the language. You can improve it to do so.

Summary: Performance improvement suggestion - rework "view holder" pattern
Description: The bug says it all: FBReaderJ on Android is probably not using the most efficient way to generate its visuals. You can improve it by learning the most efficient way and then applying it, submitting a pull request.

Summary: unit tests fail consistently when run according to instructions on "hive how to contribute" page
Description: The documentation has the wrong way to run the unit tests. You can fix this and make it easier for people to get involved in hive.

Summary: Write unit test: Improve support for storing files on Amazon S3
Description: (This is a fairly large issue.) A contributor has written a patch that improves how Hive copies files. Someone needs to write an automated test that covers this code.

Summary: Fix column names in FileSinkOperator
Description: (Note: I, your editor, don't quite understand this task. But you know hive, you might.) Under some circumstances, hive uses virtual column names when it could use real column names. Fixing this would improve usability.

Summary: Resolve issue where SELECTing data with NULLs causes row to not be visible
Description: When quering hbase with hive, if a column contains a NULL value, then the row is simply not output at all.

Summary: Add one line to bootstrap.sh script, for compatibility
Description: Submit a patch adding the one line (per spaetz's final remark) required

Summary: Document the config options available in config_spec.ini
Description: Since the code provides a sample configuration file, you can use a "symbolic link" to make that available within the docs/ directory, and then write a small bit of English text explaining that file.

Summary: CSS overflow fixes: Overflow not handled at pages like delete media ones
Description: Take an existing patch and clean it up, so that it meets the requests of the project's main maintainer.

Summary: New screenshots for the MediaGoblin site
Description: Run the code on your computer, and take fresh screenshots that correspond to the same content as the screenshots on the current mediagoblin.org site. Share those screenshots by attaching them to the ticket, so that the maintainer of the project can update the website with those screenshots.

Summary: Write unit test for pagination (i.e. clicking 'next')
Description: Right now, the MediaGoblin project lets you click 'next' and 'previous' to go between pages of media. The project wants the code that provides these prev/next links to be covered by automated tests.

Summary: Fix possible format string bug
Description: A fan of octave automatically checked the source code for format string bugs related to the size of string buffers, and found a probable issue. You should investigate the issue and write on the issue a remark as to if you think the automatic check got it right. Preferably, also submit a patch.

Summary: bicubic needs documentation of "spline_alpha" argument
Description: A previous patch changed some code, and was partially applied, but the documentation portion of that patch got dropped by accident. You should find that patch, make sure it still applies to the project, and then submit the part that needs to still be applied.

Summary: MATLAB's mex accepts options not in Octave's version
Description: Modify the command line tool 'mex' so that it is more Matlab compatible. It seems to me you should add support for '-O' as a no-op, for '-output' as equivalent to '--output', and in the case of '--largeArrayDims' print an error but also link to a documentation page about compatibility issues with mex. (It might be wise to simply link to that compatibilitiy page in the case of any mex error.)

Summary: run('path/to/file') doesn't when ".m" is missing - test the fix
Description: The submitted provided a patch. It is useful to the maintainer if other people indicate that the patch works for them.

Summary: printf with empty arguments is inconsistent with Matlab
Description: You would need to find the implementation of printf within Octave, and patch it.

Summary: Advanced: Fix empirical probability distribution implementation and docs
Description: It seems empirical_pdf() and discrete_pdf() may be implemented wrong in Octave. Generate some test cases for them, and if you can, fix the underlying bugs.

Summary: convn(x,y,"valid") produces results that are different from Matlab
Description: The submitted provided a patch. It is useful to the maintainer if other people indicate that the patch works for them. Additionally, the patch could use unit tests.

Summary: Some notices messages which can maybe fixed
Description: Read through the relevant part of the code, and make sure you agree that the code issues have been solved. If so, fix the documentation issue described on the ticket.

Summary: Comment permalink wrong when only listing one comment type
Description: The wp_list_comments() function should be smarter about pagination, as described on the ticket. Submit a patch!

Summary: screenshots of plugins from wordpress.org load over http instead of https when FORCE_SSL_ADMIN is enabled
Description: Configure your WordPress accordingly, and then enable the Beta Tester plugin as suggested, and then leave a note on the bug indicating if it is fixed.

Summary: Bug in the bar graph tutorial
Description: Per the ticket, the tutorial is not entirely accurate with the current version of d3. Submit a Github pull request to fix the tutorial.

Summary: Unclear wording in bar graph tutorial
Description: Per the ticket, there is a small bit of the tutorial that could be easier to read. Improve it in the way described.

Summary: portuguese_en.doctest is broken
Description: The code provided in the documentation (portuguese_en.doctest) supposedly does not actually work with Python 2.x. Get Python 2.x and try to run the code in that file, and see if it does or doesn't work for you, and update the ticket accordingly. Bonus points if you can figure out what the actual problem is.

Summary: Test that the graphical interface works in Python 3
Description: Per the ticket, the maintainers think that some of the graphical tools bundled with NLTK don't work properly when the user is using Python 3.x. You should try the various graphical tools (GUIs) and report on the ticket what problems or successes you have.

Summary: (Advanced) Unseen token error in nltk.model.NgramModel.entropy
Description: Solving this ticket requires a knowledge of the basics of N-gram models in language processing, but would be very rewarding.

Summary: Porter stemmer's output inconsistent with that of reference implementations
Description: The goal of the bug is to submit a pull request adding more tests to test/stem.doctest that show precisely what errors NTLK is making.

Summary: (Advanced) make some good doctests for nltk.model.NgramModel
Description: The goal here is to submit a pull request with a *.doctest file that covers the basic use of the NGramModel within NLTK. Therefore you would need to know (or be willing to learn about) what n-gram models in language processing are.

Summary: corpus reader docstrings
Description: Write some simple documentation on what the purpose of some parts of the code are. Fairly easy.

Summary: Add Footer to Layout
Description: Edit this Rails app, improving the design by copying from one part to another.

Summary: (Advanced) Random Resource Identifiers
Description: Taking this task, you will write automated tests for Rails code and make the Privly web app more secure

Summary: Put Meta Tags onto Page for Previewing Content
Description: Make small changes to the Rails templates so that when you link to a page generated by the app on Facebook, it shows you some useful information.

Summary: (Advanced) Fix problem with assigning temporary folder for data storage.
Description: Passing -tmp and a location does not change where temporary data is stored.  Replicate that this error exists, and attempt to fix it.

Summary: Fix user interface problem on Windows
Description: Verify if the bug exists on Windows, and then attempt to fix it.  Should probably be comfy working with python-generated GUIs/IO.

Summary: Combine two redundant constants into one.
Description: Replace instances of "FINISHED" with "STOPPED".  As you do so, check that it's not unique behavior.

Summary: Add "stop" and "start" parameters to playing audio.
